title: Good Eats
name: Good Eats
description:
A Map by Asmaa

Good music and good food go hand in hand. We've highlighted some recommendations from Gazette restaurant critics.

properties.name: Chez Bong
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1012 St. Laurent Blvd. montreal1012 St. Laurent Blvd., near Viger St., 514-396-7779. Open Tues. to Sun. 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; closed Mon. Licensed. MC, Visa. Like a Korean Chalet BBQ, Chez Bong’s wood-panelled room draws diners with sizzling platters of meats, including beef ribs in saty-sweet marinade. Greasy deep-fried dumplings, pork, kimchi and tofu stir-fry, and spicy soups are a little heavy but very homemade. (Sarah Musgrave, May 2007) Korean Good bet $ $

properties.name: Hanashima
properties.description: Posted by Asmaade 75 la Gauchetière St. W. montreal75 la Gauchetière St. W. 514-396-4746. Lunch and dinner daily. Licensed. Visa, Mastercard and Interac. From the realm of DIY dining comes Japanese shabu shabu, an unusual hot-potting experience in which customers custom-cook their meals at individual cooking stations. There are three bubbling broths (chicken, traditional and spicy) for simmering spinach-like greens, cabbage, enoki mushrooms, daikon, watercress and other veggies, along with your choice of finely sliced meats or seafood. Good clean fun, down to the sesame or green tea ice cream for dessert. (Sarah Musgrave, March 2007) Japanese Good bet $ $

properties.name: Kremlin
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1015 Beaver Hall montreal1015 Beaver Hall Hill, 514-876-0555. Mon.-Sat. 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. or later. Licensed. Cavernous Kremlin is dedicated to the esthetics and the eats of the former USSR. Under hammer and sickle insignia, waitresses in Soviet youth camp outfits deliver decently prepared rib-sticking meats and starches, from varenecki dumplings to beef blinchike rolls to chicken schnitzel, along with a surprisingly succulent eggplant appetizer. (Sarah Musgrave, Aug. 2006) Soviet Fair bet $ $

properties.name: La Iguana
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa51 Roy St. E. montreal51 Roy St. E. 514-844-0893. Dinner Sun.-Wed. 5 p.m.-11 p.m.; Thurs. 5 p.m.-midnight; Fri. 5 p.m.-midnight., Sat. 5 p.m.-midnight. Licensed. Visa, MC, Interac. Not an address for authentic comida mexicana but for kitschy cocktails and copious cheesy offerings. Stuffed jalapeños and chicken enchiladas in brandy sauce fare better than traditional recipes like cochinita pibil. (Sarah Musgrave, Aug. 2004) Tex-Mex Fair bet $ $

properties.name: La Paryse
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa302 Ontario St. montreal qc302 Ontario St. E. (514) 842-2040 Open Tues. to Fri. 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.; Sat. noon to 10:30 p.m.; Sun. noon to 10 p.m.; closed Mon. Licensed. All major cards. It would be clichéd to say long-standing La Paryse has “the best burgers in town,” but the all-beef patties at this cutesy diner are certainly a few grinds above the average. Vegetarians aren\'t the underclass here, however, with three burger options. Devouring sessions take place in two homey rooms in the Latin Quarter that often attract lineups in the entryway to beefdom. Accompanying your meal with a milkshake is optional, but you really oughta. (Sarah Musgrave, Mar 2006) Burgers $ Good bet

properties.name: Le Caveau
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa2063 Victoria St. (514) 844-1624. Lunch weekdays; dinner daily. Major cards. A Montreal institution since 1949, this charming, three-story restaurant is a great choice for a night of civilized fine dining. The unpretentious French “cuisine bourgeoise” features hearty soups and bisques, delightful salads, and delicious French classics like duck confit, bavette/frites and choucroute. On top of that there’s a small but fine selection of French wines and service is exemplary. (Lesley Chesterman, Jan. 2007) French HHH $ $ - $ $ $ $

properties.name: Le Grand Comptoir
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1225 Phillips Square montrealLe Grand Comptoir, 1225 Phillips Square (514) 393-3295 Open Mon. to Fri. 11:30 a.m. to 9 p.m. or later; Sat. noon to 10 p.m.; closed Sun. Licensed. All major cards. A longtime fixture on Phillips Square, Le Grand Comptoir\'s goal in life is to stay true to the standards of French cuisine. Cheap and classique if not particularly chic, it does most of its business at lunch, catering to workers and shoppers in the city core who have meat with sauce in mind, be that sirloin steak with Roquefort, or pork tenderloin in cream and mustard. (Sarah Musgrave, Dec 2006) French 60523 Good bet

properties.name: Le Latini
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1130 Jeanne Mance St montreal

properties.name: Le Nil Bleu
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa3706 St. Denis St.

properties.name: Le Piemontais
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1145 de Bullion Ave. montreal1145 de Bullion Ave. 514-861-8122. Lunch weekdays; dinner Mon.-Sat. Major cards. A well-loved Italian restaurant popular with celebrating families and the Radio-Canada crowd. Cuisine is solid Italian/Canadian fare. Outstanding service. Excellent and affordable wine list. As Place des Arts is just a few blocks north, it’s a good pick for pre- or post-concert supper. (Lesley Chesterman, Feb. 2007) Italian HH 1ž2 $ $ $

properties.name: MAP
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa2 sherbrooke st. e. montreal 2 Sherbrooke St. E., 514-843-8881. Open Mon. to Fri. 11:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.; Tues. to Sat. 6 p.m. to 11 p.m.; Sun. closed. Licensed. All major cards. A converted casse-croûte redone in beige and gold is a sunny spot for Basque-style tapas, small plates inspired by land and sea. Though it\'s run by nearby resto Pinxtos, the northern Spanish fare is somehow less convincing and less compelling here. Calamari, quail and scallop dishes conveyed adventurousness, main courses came across as simply average, and dessert of caramel-laced profiteroles captured the attention. (Sarah Musgrave, April 2007) Basque $ Fair to Good Bet

properties.name: Osaka
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa2137 Bleury St. montreal2137 Bleury St., 514-849-3438. Lunch Tues.-Fri. 11:45 a.m. to 2 p.m.; supper Tues. to Thurs. 6 p.m. to 9:30 p.m.; Fri. 6 p.m. to 10:15 p.m.; Sat. 5:30 p.m. to 10:15 p.m.; Sun. to 9 p.m.; closed Mon. Licensed. MC, Visa. Cozy and cluttered, Osaka’s subterranean setting feels like a quirky family restaurant in Japan, with its decor of retro lunchroom fixtures and paper screens. The sushi isn’t stellar, but lesser-known Japanese specialties are worth a try: hamachi-kama (yellowtail tuna neck), chawan mushi (saline egg custard spotted with green onions), agedashi tofu flavoured with ginger and soy, and comfy mains like rice-based domburis. (Sarah Musgrave, March 2007) Japanese Good bet $ $

properties.name: Pullman
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa3424 Parc Ave montreal3424 Parc Ave. (514) 288-7779 Open Tues. to Sat. 4:30 p.m. to 1 a.m. Licensed. All major cards. This stylish wine bar conjures up an old-fashioned appreciation for the finer things, from warm hand towels to vintage labels to fancy finger foods. Oysters Rockefeller or venison tartare are graciously served beneath a stemware chandelier that glints with the sounds of decidedly modern music. (Sarah Musgrave, Dec 2004 ) Wine bar 60513 Good bet

properties.name: Restaurant Julien
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa 1191 Union Ave montreal1191 Union Ave. 514-871-1581. Lunch weekdays, dinner Mon to Sat. Major cards. Wheelchair access. If you\'re looking for a good square meal, an appealing setting and solicitous service, this is the restaurant for you. When ordering stick to classics like calf\'s liver with onions and duck salads. Desserts are a must, as is a bottle of wine, for the wine list here is interesting and well priced. In the summer, the gorgeous, posey-laden terrasse is a great spot for a power lunch or a romantic dinner. (Lesley Chesterman, April 2006) Bistro HH $ $ $

properties.name: Restaurant Laloux
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa 250 AVENUE DES PINS EST, montreal250 Pine Ave. E. 514-287-9127. Lunch Mon.- Fri.; dinner daily. Major cards. Wheelchair access. For close to two decades, this “bistro de luxe” has been a gourmet oasis for diners eager for fine food, even finer wines and a gorgeous Gallic setting. Now with the arrival of the talented team of chef Danny St-Pierre and pastry chef Patrice Demers, this chic resto is flying high again, with the focus now on re-worked bistro classics such as coq au vin, braised lamb shoulder, hot foie gras, and pot de crème – all at more than reasonable prices. (Lesley Chesterman, May 2007) French HHH $ $ - $ $ $

properties.name: Sur Bleury
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1067 Bleury St. montreal1067 Bleury St. (514) 866-6161 Open Mon. & Tues. 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Wed. to Fri. 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. & 5 p.m. to 10 p.m.; closed weekends. Licensed. Visa, MC. It\'s not that this lofty sandwich and salad spot is doing anything so out of the ordinary, it\'s just that what it does do, it pulls off with a certain breezy optimism. Try trout gravlax and beet salad, pan-fried fish and pineapple sandwich with lime labneh or grilled cheese with aged Quebec cheddar and caramelized pear, and follow up with a mini pot au chocolat flavoured with Baileys for dessert. In the evening, a series of small plates includes an upscale version of poutine. (Sarah Musgrave, May 2005) Sandwiches 60522 Great Bet

properties.name: Zen-Ya
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa486 ST CATHERINE W montreal486 Ste.Catherine St. W. (2nd floor) 514-904-1363. Lunch Mon.-Fri; dinner daily. Major cards. Located in an obscure walk-up in the heart of the city, this Japanese restaurant with a stunning contemporary decor offers a diverse and exotic menu. Sushi aficionados will not be disappointed. However, the wait staff is a bit too casual. Better at lunch, when reservations are recommended. (Lesley Chesterman, June 2006) Japanese HH 1ž2 $ $ $
